Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Teacher Leadership: Investigating the Persistence and Trajectories of Noyce Master Teaching Fellows
Award.AbstractNarration: The overarching goal of this collaborative Noyce Track 4 Research project is to contribute to the currently-limited understanding of STEM teacher leadership by examining the influences of teacher leadership development on the persistence and professional trajectories of Noyce Master Teaching Fellows (MTFs). The Teacher Leadership (T-Lead) project plans to gather data related to the nature and structure of seven currently active Noyce MTF projects, the professional trajectories of participating MTFs, the school contexts in which the MTFs teach, and the leadership activities in which they engage. This data set will allow the project team to address two main research objectives. The first is to determine the impact of the professional learning models used in the various Noyce projects on the professional identities and trajectories of participating MTFs, and look for patterns in the features of those models that may be correlated with teacher persistence. The second is to explore how different contextual factors (e.g. STEM teaching responsibilities, school culture), professional networks, and leadership opportunities shape the decisions of MTFs to remain in classroom roles during and/or after the Noyce program. Additionally, the data may support initial conversations around the opportunities in K-12 systems that engage classroom teachers as leaders. Such data-supported discussions related to teacher persistence could look at what are sustainable, scalable models that do or could exist to provide such opportunities in ways that positively affect teacher persistence. In summary, this Noyce Track 4 Research grant could further the overarching goal of the Noyce program by determining what the structure and mechanisms of STEM teacher leader efforts are that support teacher persistence in high-need school districts.<br/><br/>The T-Lead project will study seven Noyce MTF projects from across the country that include both in-progress and completed professional learning experiences dedicated to the development of STEM teacher leaders. These projects involve 159 MTFs from across the K-12 spectrum, all of whom have STEM teaching responsibilities. Data collected will include surveys and interviews with MTFs, administrators and peer teachers at their schools, and PIs of the Noyce projects; analysis of project design features; and artifacts from project and teacher leadership activities. Both qualitative (e.g. coding of interview data) and quantitative analysis will be conducted to determine patterns of project structure, leadership opportunities, and school culture, which may impinge on MTFs' persistence in the profession. Quantitative data analysis will use Structural Equation Modeling and Hierarchical Linear Modeling of survey data. Data collection and analysis will converge from a comprehensive examination of the projects and participants to carefully-selected case studies that are intended to help map typical master teaching fellow trajectories. The results of this project will be disseminated through numerous local, state and regional outlets (e.g. local teacher leadership efforts, state meetings and conferences and national research and STEM teacher educator conferences). The findings are intended to help future Noyce and related projects better design professional learning for teacher leaders and better understand the unique challenges of STEM teachers that may impact their persistence.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Teacher Leadership (T-LEAD) project, a Track 4 grant through the National Science Foundation’s Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, examines the influences of teacher leadership development on the professional trajectories of Noyce Master Teaching Fellows (MTFs). T-LEAD is a collaborative research project among the University of Nebraska–Lincoln, Middle Tennessee State University, West Chester University, and the University of South Carolina.

T-LEAD studies MTF projects at Auburn University; California State University, San Bernardino; the University of Cincinnati; the University of Colorado Boulder; Kennesaw State University; the University of Nebraska-Lincoln; the University of South Carolina; and Michigan Technological University, with the goal to understand the influence of teacher leadership development on the persistence of teachers.

Researchers gathered data related to the nature and structure of these Noyce programs, the professional trajectories of participating MTFs, the school contexts in which the MTFs operate, and the leadership activities in which they engage. The team has developed a pair of codebooks to capture the phenomenon embedded in the interview data. The original interview codebook allows the team to explore the interactions between MTFs’ personal and professional characteristics, the school culture and resources, and the Noyce projects’ programmatic features. It makes visible effects at the individual level and the system level. The more recent professional vision codebook has brought a new lens on teacher leadership and provided some valuable insights as to how the capacity to highlight, code, and reify the experiences in school contexts influences the work of teacher leaders.

Researchers looked at the data through the lens of professional vision and have published a blog with AAAS / ARISE on this topic. The team is investigating the construct of professional vision among these MTFs and how it intersects with the development of teachers’ leadership identities. Teacher leaders are intuitively aware of the role of a professional vision in key aspects of teacher leadership, such as mentoring. The lens of professional vision also allows the project leaders to ask questions such as, ‘Why did some professional learning communities diminish their professional development during the pandemic while others strengthened it?’, and consider how Noyce can fill the gap in cases where the professional vision and development was diminished.

The large data set collected with the project’s survey instrument allows for comparisons in outcomes between the Noyce and non-Noyce teacher leadership development efforts, revealing recommendations for best practices in teacher leadership support and development. The analysis showed that Noyce had a significant impact on the relationship between MTFs’ self-efficacy as teacher leaders and their school contexts, mediating that relationship through the way the MTFs viewed the resources at their disposal.

In addition to looking across Noyce projects, T-LEAD also looked closely at each project individually. Nebraska identified several key features of Noyce in supporting teachers’ growth as leaders: the coursework associated with the program, the community of practice that the teachers developed, and the resources provided to teachers for carrying out teacher leadership activities. A critical finding for the Cincinnati team was that the MTFs’ work around mentoring connected their schools and Noyce communities of practice, changing their meaning for mentoring and causing more recognition of the importance of mentoring in terms of teacher retention. In the Colorado Noyce program, MTFs were included in the project’s research communities of practice, which strengthened the teachers’ teacher-leader identities. It was also found those schools that shared the boundary object of an epistemological commitment to evidence-based practice more readily allowed the transfer of ideas and approaches from the Noyce community than those schools that did not share this boundary object.

T-Lead also made its mark on the full spectrum of research assistants who participated in various components of the research process. Graduate research assistants have been involved throughout the project and received mentoring in: research design; survey instrument development; document coding; conducting semi-structured interviews; creating and using a codebook to code interviews; using qualitative coding software; and conducting quantitative analyses on survey data (e.g., exploratory factor analysis). This mentoring also was afforded to an undergraduate student, representing a span of developmental stages from undergraduates through post-doctoral candidates.
